column1: What does it mean for vectors to be linearly dependent?
column2: At least one vector can be written as a linear combination of the others.

column1: What does it mean for vectors to be linearly independent?
column2: None of the vectors in the set can be written as a linear combination of the others.

column1: What is the geometric interpretation of linearly dependent vectors in 2D?
column2: They lie on the same line (are colinear).

column1: What is the geometric interpretation of linearly independent vectors in 2D?
column2: They span the plane — each adds a unique direction.

column1: How can we computationally check for linear independence using PyTorch?
column2: By stacking vectors into a matrix and comparing the matrix rank with the number of vectors.

column1: What does matrix rank represent in this context?
column2: The number of linearly independent vectors — the dimension of the space they span.

column1: What is the condition for linear dependence using the zero vector?
column2: A set is linearly dependent if c₁v₁ + c₂v₂ + ... + cₙvₙ = 0 has a nontrivial solution (not all cᵢ = 0).

column1: What does it mean when the rank of a matrix formed by vectors is less than the number of vectors?
column2: The vectors are linearly dependent — some are redundant.

column1: Why does a set of 3 vectors in ℝ² have to be linearly dependent?
column2: Because at most 2 vectors can span ℝ²; the third must be a combination of the first two.

column1: Why is linear independence important when defining a basis?
column2: Because a basis must consist of vectors that uniquely span the space — no vector should be redundant.

column1: What is the relationship between matrix rank and basis?
column2: The rank gives the number of independent vectors — the size of the largest basis you can form from the set.

column1: Are the vectors [2,3] and [4,6] linearly dependent or independent?
column2: Dependent — they are colinear and one is a multiple of the other.

column1: Are the vectors [7,0] and [0,-1] linearly dependent or independent?
column2: Independent — they point in orthogonal directions.

column1: Why is [1,2] redundant in the set {[2,1], [3,2], [1,2]}?
column2: It can be written as a linear combination of the other two vectors — the set is dependent.

column1: How do we determine whether a set of vectors spans ℝ³?
column2: Check if any vector in ℝ³ can be written as a combination of the vectors — i.e., solve the system of equations.

column1: What does it mean when a set of 3 vectors in ℝ³ has a nonzero solution to c₁v₁ + c₂v₂ + c₃v₃ = 0?
column2: The vectors are linearly dependent — some are redundant.

column1: What does it mean when the only solution to c₁v₁ + c₂v₂ + c₃v₃ = 0 is c₁ = c₂ = c₃ = 0?
column2: The vectors are linearly independent — no redundancy.

column1: Why is linear independence important in deep learning?
column2: Independent features carry unique information and help avoid redundancy and numerical instability.

column1: What is the connection between linear independence and feature selection?
column2: Independent features contribute new information — dependent ones may be redundant or correlated.
